item.description:
*NOTE! RAIN DATE SUNDAY OCT. 9     1:00 PM*

    

 

Note: Local parking is for Cambridge residents only--see details on public transport below

Cambridgeport, across the Charles from Boston is unique because much of it's architecture is intact. The land was filled in so that, as you walk from block to block, towards Central Sq. layers of time seem to peel away, visible by starkly different architectural styles you wouldn't normally notice. But that can be revealed to us through this annual walking tour of Cambridgeport. It is free to the public.

Was Cambridge really a port? Where did Magazine Island get it's name? Who were "Tory absconders"? Why are some houses in the back yards of street-front houses? How did the locals keep grazing farm animals from climbing up their front porches? Why are some houses mirror images of each other? What did Cambridgeport have to do with oyster harvesting? Where were the original shorelines? Tramlines? What is the "greasy village"?

Don't forget your camera!
For those who are not Cambridge residents, car-parking is unrestricted on Sunday. But on Saturday you can go to the Green St. parking garage, 260 Green St. From there head down Pearl St. (at the corner of this parking lot), six blocks (in the opposite direction of Central Sq.) to Lawrence St. then turn right for one block.

Public transportation would be, get to Central Sq. via the red line. Then consider taking the number 47 bus down magazine street.

The tour is run courtesy of the Cambridge Historical Commission.  

****NOTE RAIN DATE; SUNDAY, OCT. 9 -- 1:00 PM****
item.name: Walking tour of Cambridgeport sites
